etymologies: early 20th century: from German Gen, from Pangen, a supposed ultimate unit of heredity (from Greek pan- ‘all’ + genos ‘race, kind, offspring’)

definitions: (in informal use) a unit of heredity which is transferred from a parent to offspring and is held to determine some characteristic of the offspring
shortDefinitions: (in informal use) unit of heredity which is transferred from parent to offspring

definitions: (in technical use) a distinct sequence of nucleotides forming part of a chromosome, the order of which determines the order of monomers in a polypeptide or nucleic acid molecule which a cell (or virus) may synthesize.
shortDefinitions: (in technical use) distinct sequence of nucleotides forming part of chromosome, order of which determines order of monomers in polypeptide
